newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russia's Yakovlev cuts jobs by 25 pct in February.
newsitem.headline: Russia's Yakovlev cuts jobs by 25 pct in February.

text.p: Russian plane-maker Yakovlev will cut its staff of engineers and workers by 25 pct in February, a company official said on Tuesday.
An official at Aviatsionnaya Korporatsiya Yakovlev, who asked not to be named, told Reuters that the company had been preparing for the dismissals since the end of last year.
"It will be completed by the end of this month," he added, but did not say how many people would be dismissed. The size of the workforce at Yakovlev is a secret.
The official said Yakovlev had met serious financial problems because of unpaid debts owed by another aviation plant.
Yakovlev has expressed interest in buying the bankrupt Dutch plane manufacturer Fokker NV, but has never received the financial backing to go ahead with a deal.
Yakovlev said it was interested in Fokker to shore up its position in the Russian short-range plane market, of which it wants 25-30 percent by the year 2000.

Yakovlev used to be the Soviet Union's foremost designer of military aircraft and still designs naval fighter planes. It also designs passenger aircraft and produced the short-range Yak-40 and Yak-42 models.
